title: Scrapz: Trust Issues Intensify
plot_outline: When Scrapz overhears about an opportunity to solve their financial problems, they convince other mascots to join a poorly planned scheme involving the welfare office's filing cabinet. However, authority figure abuses power, leading to a series of increasingly desperate decisions that prove good intentions, terrible execution.

scenes.title: Rock Bottom Has a Basement
scenes.action: Scrapz begins their day with the usual routine of avoiding responsibility and managing expectations. The catalyst for today's adventure presents itself in the form of an overdue bill. Despite every instinct screaming "don't get involved," circumstances and poor judgment combine to draw Scrapz into the situation.

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: I don't do charity work, and I don't do favors.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: secretly hoping someone will save them

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: Everyone's got an angle, what's yours?
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: protecting themselves from further disappointment

dialogue.subtext: terrified of being vulnerable again

dialogue.speaker: Rizzo
dialogue.line: At least nobody died... this time.
dialogue.tone: dark humor as a defense mechanism against trauma
dialogue.subtext: desperately wants to be proven wrong about people

scenes.title: When Bad Gets Worse
scenes.action: The situation escalates when their simple plan attracts unwanted attention. What seemed like a manageable problem reveals itself to be connected to larger issues involving systemic inequality. Scrapz realizes they're in deeper than anticipated and that their usual strategy of "ignore it and hope it goes away" won't work this time.

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: This has 'bad idea' written all over it.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: desperately wants to be proven wrong about people

scenes.title: Same Shit, Different Day
scenes.action: The episode concludes with Scrapz having learned nothing from their experience but somehow finding themselves in a slightly different variation of the same situation they started in. Victory is redefined as "not making things significantly worse," and the audience is reminded that some problems don't get solved—they just get replaced with new problems.
